q: What helplines can I call if I'm feeling down or desperate?
a: You can call helplines such as Samaritans at 116 123, CALM at 0800 58 58 58, Papyrus at 0800 068 41 41, Childline at 0800 1111, or SOS Silence of Suicide at 0300 1020 505.

q: How can I talk to someone I trust about my feelings?
a: Let your family or friends know what's going on for you. Starting the conversation is important, and they may be able to offer support and help keep you safe.

q: Who else can I talk to if I can't talk to someone I know?
a: If you can't talk to someone you know, you can call a GP for an emergency appointment, call 111 out of hours, or contact your mental health crisis team if you have one.

q: What should I do if my life is in danger?
a: If your life is in danger or you've seriously harmed yourself, call 999 for an ambulance or go straight to A&E. You can also ask someone else to call 999 or take you to A&E.

q: What are some tips for coping right now?
a: Try not to think about the future, stay away from drugs and alcohol, get yourself to a safe place, be around other people, and do something you usually enjoy, such as spending time with a pet.

q: How can I help someone I'm worried about?
a: Try to get them to talk to you by asking open-ended questions. Just listening to what someone has to say and taking it seriously can be more helpful.

q: Where can I get information about making a safety plan?
a: You can visit the Staying Safe website for information on how to make a safety plan. You can also get information from mental health charity Mind.

q: What are some helplines I can call if I'm feeling down or desperate?
a: Here are some helplines you can call if you're feeling down or desperate: Samaritans - Call 116 123, CALM - Call 0800 58 58 58, Papyrus HOPELINE247 - Call 0800 068 41 41, Childline - Call 0800 1111, SOS Silence of Suicide - Call 0300 1020 505

q: What should I do if I'm feeling suicidal?
a: If you're feeling suicidal, it's important to tell someone you trust or contact a helpline. You can also call a GP for an emergency appointment, call 111 out of hours, or contact your mental health crisis team if you have one. If your life is in immediate danger, call 999 for an ambulance or go straight to A&E.

q: What are some tips for coping with difficult feelings right now?
a: Some tips for coping with difficult feelings right now are: try to focus on getting through today, stay away from drugs and alcohol, be in the company of others, do something you enjoy, and seek support from organizations like Rethink.

q: How can I support someone who is feeling suicidal?
a: If you're worried about someone who is feeling suicidal, try to get them to talk to you and listen to them without judgement. Samaritans and Rethink provide helpful tips on supporting someone who is having suicidal thoughts.

q: How can I make a safety plan for myself or someone else?
a: To make a safety plan for yourself or someone else, you can visit the Staying Safe website which provides information, video tutorials, and online templates to guide you through the process. You can also get information on planning for a mental health crisis from the mental health charity Mind.

q: How can I start a conversation about suicidal feelings?
a: There's no right or wrong way to start a conversation about suicidal feelings. The important thing is to initiate the conversation. You can begin by expressing concern and asking open-ended questions like 'How do you feel about...?'

q: What should I do if someone has seriously harmed themselves?
a: If someone has seriously harmed themselves or you believe their life is in immediate danger, call 999 for an ambulance or take them to the nearest A&E. It's crucial to get professional medical help in such situations.

q: What if I can't talk to someone I know about my suicidal thoughts?
a: If you find it difficult to talk to someone you know about your suicidal thoughts, you can call a GP for an emergency appointment, contact the helpline 111 out of hours, or reach out to your mental health crisis team if you have one.

q: What text lines can I contact if I don't want to talk over the phone?
a: If you prefer not to talk over the phone, you can contact the Shout Crisis Text Line by texting 'SHOUT' to 85258, or the YoungMinds Crisis Messenger by texting 'YM' to 85258. These text lines are open 24/7.

q: Where can I find more information on supporting someone who is having suicidal thoughts?
a: Samaritans provide helpful tips on how to support someone you are worried about. You can also find advice on supporting someone who is having suicidal thoughts from Rethink.

q: What helplines can I call if I'm feeling down or desperate?
a: You can call helplines such as Samaritans at 116 123, CALM at 0800 58 58 58, Papyrus at 0800 068 41 41, Childline at 0800 1111, and SOS Silence of Suicide at 0300 1020 505.

q: How can I talk to someone I trust about my feelings?
a: Let your family or friends know what's going on for you and they may offer support and help keep you safe.

q: Who else can I talk to if I find it difficult to talk to someone I know?
a: If you find it difficult to talk to someone you know, you can call your GP for an emergency appointment, call 111 out of hours, or contact your mental health crisis team.

q: What should I do if my life is in danger?
a: If you have seriously harmed yourself or feel you may harm yourself, call 999 for an ambulance or go to A&E.

q: What are some tips for coping right now?
a: Focus on getting through today, stay away from drugs and alcohol, go to a safe place, be around other people, and do something you usually enjoy.

q: What can I do if I'm worried about someone else?
a: Try to get them to talk to you by asking open-ended questions and listen to what they have to say without worrying about having the answers.

q: How can I create a safety plan for myself or someone else?
a: You can visit the Staying Safe website for information on how to make a safety plan, including video tutorials and online templates.
